title: Using radioactive drugs to see inside your body - Pedro Brugarolas

multiple-choice.question: What type of scanner is used to detect cancer cells in the body after injecting a radioactive form of glucose known as FDG?
Where is the particle accelerator, also known as a cyclotron, typically housed in hospitals?
What type of water is used as a target in the particle accelerator to produce fluorine-18?

options.label: C
options.text: Water with a heavy form of oxygen called oxygen-18

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of attaching radioactive fluorine to different molecules to create radiotracers?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect diseases such as cancer and dementia

options.label: B
options.text: To treat diseases such as cancer and dementia

options.label: C
options.text: To study the effects of radiation on the body

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new medical imaging technologies

multiple-choice.question: How does the PET scanner detect the radiation emitted by the tracer?

options.label: B
options.text: Using an array of paired radiation detectors

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the collision between a positron and an electron from another molecule in the surroundings?

options.label: A
options.text: The production of a single high-energy photon

options.label: B
options.text: The production of two high-energy photons

options.label: C
options.text: The production of a single low-energy photon

options.label: D
options.text: The production of two low-energy photons

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the benefits of using PET scans in medical diagnostics?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only detect cancer after it has spread to other parts of the body

options.label: B
options.text: They can detect the spread of cancer before it can be spotted with other types of imaging

options.label: C
options.text: They can only detect Alzheimer's disease after symptoms have appeared

options.label: D
options.text: They can only detect dementia after symptoms have appeared

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated amount of radiation exposure from a single PET scan comparable to?

options.label: A
options.text: The amount of radiation exposure from a single X-ray

options.label: B
options.text: The amount of radiation exposure from a single CT scan

options.label: C
options.text: The amount of radiation exposure over two or three years from natural radioactive sources

options.label: D
options.text: The amount of radiation exposure from a single MRI scan

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential risks associated with PET scans?

options.label: A
options.text: The risk of allergic reactions to the tracer

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of ionizing radiation exposure

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of infection from the injection site

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of anaphylaxis from the tracer

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to perform the PET scan within a few hours of producing the fluorine-18?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the fluorine-18 has a long half-life and will remain radioactive for several days

options.label: B
options.text: Because the fluorine-18 has a short half-life and will decay quickly

options.label: C
options.text: Because the patient's body will metabolize the fluorine-18 quickly

options.label: D
options.text: Because the PET scanner can only detect the radiation emitted by the fluorine-18 for a short period

options.label: C

title: The gift and power of emotional courage - Susan David

multiple-choice.question: What does the Zulu word "sawubona" literally mean?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Developing a growth mindset and being open to learning

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: She was a local of multiple cities.

options.text: The notion of a country as a fixed entity.

options.text: It implies that a person's identity is tied to a single country.

options.label: C
options.text: The former implies a fixed identity, while the latter implies a more fluid identity.

options.label: D
options.text: The former is more accurate, while the latter is less accurate.

multiple-choice.question: What does Taiye Selasi say is the problem with the concept of national identity?

options.label: C
options.text: It implies that a person's identity is tied to a single country.

options.label: D
options.text: It ignores the complexity of human experience.

options.label: A
options.text: As a citizen of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: As a national of multiple countries.

options.label: C
options.text: As a local of multiple cities.

options.label: D
options.text: As a human being, like everybody else.

title: How do ocean currents work? - Jennifer Verduin

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the cargo ship carrying bath toys in 1992?

options.label: B
options.text: It got caught in a storm and lost its cargo.

options.label: C
options.text: It ran out of fuel and was stranded.

multiple-choice.question: What drives ocean currents?

options.label: C
options.text: A range of sources including wind, tides, changes in water density, and the rotation of the Earth.

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the ocean's water is controlled by surface currents?

options.label: A
options.text: The way the Earth's rotation affects the wind patterns that give rise to ocean currents.

options.label: B
options.text: The way the wind affects the ocean's surface.

options.label: C
options.text: The way the tides affect the ocean's floor.

options.label: D
options.text: The way the ocean's density affects the currents.

multiple-choice.question: What drives deep ocean currents?

options.label: B
options.text: Primarily changes in the density of seawater

options.label: D
options.text: Primarily the rotation of the Earth

multiple-choice.question: What is thermohaline circulation?

options.text: The movement of warm water from the equator to the poles.

options.label: B
options.text: The movement of cold water from the poles to the equator.

options.label: C
options.text: A vertical current caused by changes in the density of seawater.

options.label: D
options.text: A horizontal current caused by the wind.

options.label: B
options.text: A deep ocean current that moves around the globe.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: A current that only moves in the northern hemisphere.
